passages.text: ATTEMPTED MURDER OF A MERCHART.
Ar the Bow-street Police-court, five men named:
James Palmer, Samuel Scandland, Leon Weiner,
Adolphe Weiner, and Daniel Jacoby, have been.
-charged with being concerned with a man (already
convicted) named Dusant, with attempting to

! murder Jules Tabak, a diamond merchant, and steal-
ing £2,000 worth of diamonds, Inspector Langrish
deposed that from information received he-went with
other officers and arrested the accused on the present
charge. Mr, Tabak, a diamond merchant, of 5,
Belyrave-street, Kusten-road, deposed that on
Mareh 25sh, two men came to hie house, and asked
him to show them some diamonds, Two parcels
were shown them, While the men were Jooking at
the diamonds the prisoner Palmer struck witness
two heavy blows on the head. He was stunned, the
two mon ran away, and stole one hundred and eighty
carats of diamonds, value £1,400, One of the mex*
(Dugant) was arrested, and has since been convicted

and sentenced to penal servitude. He positively
identificd Palmer as the other man, Mra, Tabed: wag
called, and identified Palmer as one of the men con-
cerned in the robbery. She did not identify him at
first, Eleanor Denunzio, the daughter of the man

Dusant, deposed that on March 25th, the day of the
robbery, the prisoner Palmer called on her and
beckoned her to the corner of the streat. He asked
for her father, He said, “I struck the old ran, Ho
screamed, and his wife came upstaira and we were
obliged to run away. I daresay your father will
blame me for all this, but my brother was outside
and did all he could to stop the servant,” Witness
asked if the servant was stopped. Prisoner replied
in the negative, She asked if her father had gos
away. Prigoner replied, ‘ No,” and told her she had
better pack up her luggage and get away from the
house at once, and leave her luggage in the cloak-
room, Elesaid, ‘ You know where Weiner lives, You
must go down to him and tell him to assist you.
Witness packed up her luggage and took it to
Waterloo Station, and afterwards wont to Adolpha
Weiuer’s house, She packed the luggage and seut if
to Waterloo Station the same day. She then wert
to G, Dyer’s Buildings, and raw Adolphe Weiner.
Directly he saw her ha said, ‘For God’s sake go
avway 1 I will meet you in Castie-etreet,’” She went
there, where-he shortly joined her, and took Jer to
a wine shop hi Chancery-lane, Witness raid, ‘Yeu
have got my father into this trouble, and I shall ex-
pect you to get him evt of it,” He denied at first
that he knew anything sbout it. She told him that
her father had told her about the affair from the
beginning, He said that all he did was to get her
father a situation, She said she knew that was
false, and that ke sent ler father to Mr. Tabak.
Firat he said he would not assist her at all, and then
he gave her 5s, and seid he would give her that

every week until she got employmont, Ho valid
whatever she did she must mot come near Dyev's
Buildings, because he was watched. Then she went
to Jasoby's house, but he was not at home, She

gaw him, however, on the following Frisay st his
place iv the Edgware-road. He sald he did net
know they were going to strike him, Witnezs told
him he musttake the money for her father’s main-
tsnance in the House of Detention, He prom
, and met witness the nex$ night in A
at, Clerkenwell, She gave him 103, for hee
On the following Monday she waa to sient
thaelles Weiner, who promised to give her £2 123.
for tha rent then due by herfather. Weiner did not
x

tura up, bat subsequently she saw Jacoby, who gave |
hes £8 to pay the rent, Ho teld her not to po to |

Weiner’s place atall, He promised to meet her at
the Marble Arch the following Wednesday, bat by
the acvive of Palmer and his wife she did uot go. On
Mare! 25th, after seoing Palmer, sho went to the hove
of his mother-in-law. He came in and sent for his
wife. They took witness to their house, and sent
for har luggage from Waterloo, She remained in the
house for nine weeks, Witness know the whale of
the prisoners, who were In the habit of coming to the
house of witness’s fathor, Three weeks after Christ-
mas Jacoby called at their house with a bottle of
chioraform, Torey tried it on the kitten. On » sub-
sequent occasion the elder Weiner took a rabbit to
the house end witness was ordered out of thea raom,
Wher she returned the windows wera open, and
there was a strong smell of chloroform in the room,
She beNeved they had tried if on tha rabbit, The
wecused, who protested thely innocence, were
remanded,
